cards.question: What is a Kubernetes namespace?
cards.answer_textbook: A logical partition that isolates resources within a cluster.
cards.answer_metaphor: Different apartments in the same building — same roof, separate spaces.
cards.answer_realworld: Namespaces let teams share one cluster safely, keeping dev, test, and prod separate.

cards.question: How do you create a new namespace?
cards.answer_metaphor: Drawing a boundary line on the playground before the chaos begins.
cards.answer_realworld: Creates an isolated scope where Deployments, Services, and Quotas live independently.

cards.question: What does changing your kubectl context namespace do?
cards.answer_textbook: Sets the default namespace for all kubectl commands in that context.
cards.answer_metaphor: Changing mailing address — all letters now go to the new office automatically.
cards.answer_realworld: Saves time; every kubectl command runs against the chosen namespace until switched back.

cards.question: What is a ResourceQuota?
cards.answer_textbook: A policy that restricts the total resource usage within a namespace.
cards.answer_metaphor: An electric meter that limits how much power your apartment can draw.
cards.answer_realworld: Defines hard CPU/memory/pod caps so one team can't exhaust cluster resources.

cards.question: How do ResourceQuotas prevent resource starvation?
cards.answer_textbook: They limit how much CPU, memory, and object count each namespace can claim.
cards.answer_metaphor: Each team gets a fixed pizza slice — no grabbing the whole pie.
cards.answer_realworld: Prevents runaway workloads from consuming all cluster resources, keeping things fair.

cards.question: How can you view current quota usage?
cards.answer_metaphor: Checking your utility bill to see how much of your budget you’ve burned.
cards.answer_realworld: Shows used vs allowed CPU, memory, and object counts.

cards.question: What happens when a namespace is deleted?
cards.answer_textbook: All resources within it are deleted too.
cards.answer_metaphor: Bulldozing the apartment — everything inside goes with it.
cards.answer_realworld: Kubernetes deletes all Deployments, Services, and Configs under that namespace.
